headline: Strategist sees Deere, Caterpillar as low-volatility AI plays
summary: STORY: "There's $640 billion in announced capex spending to grow AI compute," Mulberry explained. "That's data centers. So we can follow that money into balance sheets like John Deere, Caterpillar, even Lockheed Martin," companies that are "needed to move dirt to actually construct these very large buildings.""It's being dubbed the HALO trade," he added. "Hard Asset with Low chance of Obsolescence. These companies are going to be around for a long time with the amount of demand built up for AI computing power."

raw.headline: Strategist sees Deere, Caterpillar as low-volatility AI plays

So we can follow that money into balance sheets like John Deere, Caterpillar, even Lockheed Martin," companies that are "needed to move dirt to actually construct these very large buildings.""It's being dubbed the HALO trade," he added. "Hard Asset with Low chance of Obsolescence. These companies are going to be around for a long time with the amount of demand built up for AI computing power."

headline: 3 Reasons L3 Harris and Other Defense Stocks Are Taking a Hit
summary: Defense stocks have been running hot, but rallies don’t come without interruptions—and Wednesday counts as a big interruption for the likes of L3Harris Technologies,  Lockheed Martin  and Northrop Grumman.  Shares of defense contractors were being hit hard, even without decisively negative news.  A combination of profit-taking catalyzed by an investor day at L3Harris Technologies, moves back into software stocks, and President Donald Trump’s State of the Union speech may be responsible.

headline: LMT vs. KTOS: Which Defense Stock Is Better Positioned for 2026?
summary: Rising U.S. defense spending and modernization plans boost prospects for Lockheed Martin and Kratos Defense amid surging demand for advanced military tech.

headline: CNBC's UK Exchange newsletter: With shares up 1,200%, Rolls-Royce’s CEO has lots to shout about
